Definition: If you find that the input comment has pornographic materials and activities that offend the public's sense of decency, then classify it as obscene else classify it as non-obscene.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Guess Barron needs to babysit the dummy and supervise his tweets.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Shut up nerd. You try too hard.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment might be considered toxic but is not obscene.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Sailors found whores and coke.I'm shocked!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be considered obscene because it contains explicit language of obscenity.

Comment: Another example of how the Oahu centric political machine treats the outer islands. It's more than a shame when our politicians put the health and safety of others at risk when it is not politically expedient to their own interests. This kind of what matters to Honolulu and screw the rest of you mentality exposes a flaw in the majority take all system we rely upon here. 

A system that is bias to Oahu at the expense of all the outer islands suggests in the long run some amount of autonomy must be sought. If Oahu can not care for the outer islands, it is long overdue for the outer islands to be granted the right, and share of state funds, to care for themselves.

We have seen this inequity played out time and time again. From our schools to our infrastructure needs. Our healthcare facilities lack, our environmental concerns are not protected, we are not protected from invasive species, but damn Oahu gets its rail. At some point there's got to be a reckoning. 

Thank you Russell.

Comment: No one knows how to gauge te outcome based on the ranked ballot.  But isn't the challenge greater than that?   
Each EDA counts as 100 points and the first candidate to get 16901 points, or more, is the winner.  This means that EDA's with a small number of members carry a lot of weight.  If one candidate has 28% support concentrated in many EDA's with few members, that candidate ha a much better chance than another candidate with 35% support concentrated in a few ridings in the GTA.
This is the same approach the Liberals used to choose Justin Trudeau.  Apparently, he had broad support getting over 80% of the points on the first round.  This time around, it seems like a real crap shoot.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: As I watched 9 more pre-orders roll in today, I had to think, darn, that's 9 more traction non-indicators for Steve.

Your opinion that pre-orders aren't a viable traction indicator is, frankly, nonsense. We clearly articulate preorders as "strong leads" in our offering circular. They are-- anyone who's put cash down, refundable or not, is a much stronger lead than someone who merely signs up for a test drive. Yes, we still have to build a compelling product, and continue to communicate that product to our pre-order customers. While some will certainly fall off, to me it seems likely they will more than be made up for from folks who are unwilling to place a preorder on something that is not yet in production, which is a very common refrain we hear.

Anyway, thanks for the positive home-town encouragement. Means a lot!

Comment: It's raining outside.....must be those damn public employees causing it... The PERS unfunded mandate is a creation of public employERS taking the "short, easy way out" and not funding the "PERS-pick-up" as it was due.  Instead they delayed payment of those funds until retirement.  Consequently, that "unfunded mandate" grew each year for each employee.  Had those public employers paid the PERS pick-up each month along with the "employer contribution", there would be virtually NO unfunded mandate.  Folks shouldn't blame the public employees.  It was the legislature, school boards, city and county governments, et al who chose to NOT pay the contribution as it was "credited" to employee retirement accounts.... This, as we're seeing today, was a MASSIVE mistake. Gary Crum

Comment: We do love the Church. If we didn't, we would have left years ago. We reject YOUR idea of the Church, but that's something else entirely.

Religious music is one of the best examples of "Sturgeon's Law" I know of (the science fiction writer Theodore Sturgeon was told, "Ninety percent of sf is crud", to which he replied "Ninety percent of EVERYTHING is crud".) Yes, today's music also exemplifies Sturgeon's Law.

BTW, Montanism was not condemned solely for having women priests. It was largely condemned for its theological beliefs. Your statement is simplistic at best.

We think about the teachings. If they give us good arguments, we accept them. Crap gets rejected. The arguments against ordaining women are crap, for example.

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

Comment: A party of five tourists from Nome, accompanied by an old-timer chef, travel by snowmachines to Fairbanks. During the first day goings-on, the tourist are rude and obnoxious. That evening, the chef includes a handful of moose nuggets to the stew. He asks the tourists, "How's the stew?" Their answer, "Tastes like moose shit!" Just then the chef pulls out a revolver and says, "The next complaint will be met with lead." Along the trail the following day, no rude behavior and all is quiet. That night the chef adds more nuggets to the stew. No complaints. Third night, the chef adds more nuggets. Still, no complaints. Fourth night, just outside Fairbanks, the chef asks, "How's the stew?" The tourists reply, "Tastes like moose shit...but good!"

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: The selfish thing gets thrown around a lot, but guess what? Everyone is selfish. Basically every choice is selfish. Ask any parent why they had kids and it will start with "I want/wanted."

Guess who is funding your playgrounds and parks? Yup, we're putting money in on that too. 

It isn't all about being so obsessed with getting something out of the world. There are plenty of us who look at the tax breaks parents are entitled to and get pretty pissed off when we don't get nearly as much back compared to what we pay in. We're often subsidizing YOUR choices---not the other way around. 

Not to mention the fact that there are MANY reason why someone might opt not to have kids. Better to not have kids than to be a shitty parent. No one made you the life police. Get over it.

Comment: JB is right; climate change can have some pretty dramatic effects.  Since the pass of the Last Glacial Maximum, sea levels have risen over 100 m, drowning immense areas of low-lying tropical rainforests in SE Asia, cutting off Britain from the rest of Europe, submerging island habitats beneath the waves.  In the meantime, changes in rainfall and snowfall transformed huge swathes of the American West from a fruitful terrane of lakes and meadows and streams to a semi-arid wasteland - leading to the demise of hundreds of species of iconic mammals, birds, and fish.  (Haven't seen a mastodon or a giant ground sloth lately, have you??)  Similarly, North Africa went from a verdant land of rivers, woods, and grasslands, populated by people and magnificent African game, to the world's largest desert.

*And the Democratic Party didn't do a damn thing to stop it!*

It's true!  :)   (Man, that sure determines how *I'm* going to vote!)

Comment: "Lies, damned lies, and statistics" is a phrase describing the persuasive power of numbers, particularly the use of statistics to bolster weak arguments. It is also sometimes colloquially used to doubt statistics used to prove an opponent's point. Wikipedia Reference to Mark Twain's dubious attribution of this to Benjamin Disraeli.

I read the research mentioned and I would cite the following:
-The sample size in this study allows the authors to come to the conclusion they want to come to in the first place
-Oregon Live has an article on the worst Oregon wildfires, http://www.oregonlive.com/wildfires/index.ssf/2017/09/the_worst_wildfires_in_oregon.html
-Of these, half are brush fires
-The others are forest fires. All were in old growth or reburns of previous fires that did not get salvaged
-The Elliot Forest, became state ownership after the original old growth was burnt around 1880.
-The B&B Complex, Whitewater Fire, Eagle Creek, Strawberry Wilderness, all unmanaged lands

Comment: I also agree. “Affordable housing” is usually thought of as co-op type stuff for the lower middle class and below. This crisis is affecting even the upper middle class (and possible higher). So building “affordable housing” comes off sounding as, “let’s just house the formally middle class who built this country after WWII in crappy low-income housing projects.”

So what’s the actual answer? Well, let me address that by first rewriting your sentence so that it’s more precise…

“There is a shortage of housing in Vancouver due to FOREIGN demand.”

The answer is simple: Shut. The. Damn. Door. Or make the foreign tax 30%. Hell, make it 100%. Make them work to be here, rather than just giving away our country one parcel of residential real estate at a time.

What we have here is a staggering — dare I say treasonous — failure of public policy and of leadership.

Comment: ..."It's rad," a friend assured me. "It's a punk bar, but it's like super friendly. And they got cheap PBR." I was down. So I met them around 9:30 pm, pedaling to the place on track bike I bought off an Alpenrose racer. The directions were vague in the best sort of way. "Just look for a door," the friend told me. I pedaled down the street, looking for that door the way you look for treasure. Eventually, I found it. At the time, I didn't know I'd be opening that door on a near weekly basis for the next two years. But the best bars are like that. You don't plan on being a regular. You just become one. The Know became my home in a way that Portland became my home. Anyhow, that first night we stayed until close, buying round after round of PBR. We talked about dreams and hopes and decisions and goals and books and bikes and beers and girls. We found love at The Know...

Comment: A few years back, WSF raised the rates for the San Juan ferries (rather steeply)  more than they did the rest of the system to recover the extra costs associated with the longer runs.    Now that the goal is to raise revenue, they have applied an across the board increase.   Since this is applied to our "cost based" fare it means that simply because of our longer runs, we are paying a greater share of the revenue increase than the shorter, cheaper runs.    In effect, we are subsidizing the South Sound runs.

User fees and fares are complicated.   I would rather just pay taxes to support all of our transportation systems (the ferries are a tiny part of the overall state transportation budget.)    User fees are a regressive tax and it is never possible to make them fair.

Comment: I agree interesting find.  Asset wise it has a lot of appeal with a fairly diverse global presence.  From a dividend investment perspective my concern is stability of the dividend.  With only 3 annual payments made it is hard to get a sense as to whether the dividend is variable or more "set" like it is with your typical NA utility.  A quick review of the statements indicates that there is a minimum cash reserve requirement or 20% of Net Income that can't be paid out, S. Korean tax rules that impact payout, as well as a number of debt issues that do not pay interest if the company doesn't pay a dividend.  So definitely some interesting nuances to be considered.

I plan to spend a bit more time with it particularly with this weekend being on the cold side.

Comment: 60% of the current budget deficit is due to increasing health care costs, which are continuing to rise. That has nothing to do with PERS. No way should public employees be singled out to pay for that.

PERS has been reformed (benefits reduced) over 20 times since 1995. Since 2000, the final salary  replacement ratio has on average been cut just about in half--and it is still falling. 

Past PERS recipients--especially those who retired circa 2000--got what everyone agrees was an outrageous deal. Current public employees have no chance of anything near that, yet people still use them as a target. The current anti-retirement measures and amendments in Ways and Means will damage some groups of public employees--and is causing panic among many nearing retirement--but they will yield almost nothing in savings. 

It's time for the legislature to stop aiming at yieldless and diversionary targets and get serious about savings and revenue reform.

Comment: Entropy is a physical concept descriptive of the evolution of matter and energy to its most probable state.  Put red and black marbles in a bag.  Most likely the red and black will be mixed.  This is entropy, progression of ordered states to disordered states simply because disordered states are more probable.  Energy can be expended to decrease local entropy (i.e. degree of disorder).  Thus as long as the sun shines or fossil fuel exists, we can reverse local entropy.

Comment: To qualify for Nexus you must be a US or Canadian citizen and agree to a police check and in-person interview by both countries.

You need to agree to give up a lot more privacy. Both the US and Canadian government now have my iris scan and fingerprints. Something they did not have before. 

Currently there are no bio-metric scans necessary for Nexus users at land boarder crossings. You simply slow down and wave your card at the card reader when driving cross the boarder. Having to get out and do an iris scan would be impractical.

Signing up for Nexus takes about 2-3 months depending on what boarder crossing you apply to. And, you need to be interviewed in person at a  place with both US and Canadian boarder agencies - e.g. Pearson, Peace Bridge, etc. 

So it is not for everyone and certainly needs a lot more administrative overhead.

Finally, I believe Sessions is also in favour of having the same process when exiting the US. Much like China. This will double the cost and delays.

Comment: Never heard it called Cow Parsnip until I moved to Anchorage. In Kodiak, it's called pushki exclusively and it grows EVERYWHERE. All children grew up with a fear of pushki burns and knew that if you accidently got the juice on you, not to let the sun see it and run to the hose for a rinse. I remember pulling my arms and sometimes my face into my t-shirt to pass through a thicket, or doing a wide sweep with my leg to stomp them down. The stalks are hollow, so it's very easy to do, even for a kid. Then in fall, when the stalks dry and harden, we would sword fight with them.

Comment: "...."marriage," by definition, meant one man, one woman ..."

Actually no. The definition restricting it to one man one woman unions was only introduced into USA law 2004/5/6 across numerous states in a frantic attempt to avoid courts making similar findings to those of the Massachusetts Supreme court ruling.
Prior to that it had always been expressly defined as between "two people", which is what triggered the Massachusets challenge.

The fact that only opposite sex marriages were performed in the past, does not mean marriage was defined as only between opposite sex couples, it simply illustrates that couples who were not opposite sex were being denied a fundamental right.

The evidence of the existence of discrimination is not proof that the discrimination was justified or justifiable.

Comment: There are not enough 1%'ers to soak, in order to pay for Trudeau's spending problem.  

A tax grab such as a hike to capital gains or dividends taxes would also affect the middle class (think seniors or workers with no pensions who have worked hard to save and have lost contribution room in their TFSAs thanks to Trudeau).  

Capital gains exclusions or dividend tax credits are NOT boutique tax credits, and any proposed unfavourable changes should be taken off the table, not only for this budget but also subsequent years.  

At a 75% inclusion rate, Canada's capital gains tax rates would be effectively double those in the U.S. following Trump's tax cuts, and that would result in capital outflows (human and financial); not conducive to higher GDP or job creation.

Comment: Ah Phillip I hear your frustration but if we look specifically at climate change, I have been, and still am, involved on a technical basis (not managerial, administrative or environmental; let alone political) in some of the few climate change (CDM / UNFCCC) projects in SA and Africa. These were initiated by the Kyoto Protocol and many countries took full, er, very much too full, advantage of the schemes that gave good income.  But not SA or Africa. Politicians and government agencies interfered (the SA CEF for example), set mad conditions, delayed and obfuscated. By the time they were vaguely organised (and its still a mess in SA today), the horse had bolted.  The low hanging fruit had been plucked (as had a lot of European countries), the 2008 financial crisis arrived and the not so ethical schemers, mainly towards Asia, were pretty much exposed.  CER's went from say 10US$ to maybe 1US$ if you are lucky. So for every finger you point at say Europe, there could be 3 pointing back.

Comment: If the 2nd Amendment truly seems the sticking point for any sort of gun "control," why not change the Amendment itself? We've done it before and can do it again. That sort of change would certainly be a bitter battle on both sides, but it's an option to consider.
For the record, I'm in favor of gun rights. I've owned guns and probably shot several thousand rounds, so please don't accuse me of being a "gun grabbin' liberal," but at the same time I have zero connection with the NRA or gun manufacturing lobby, so don't tar me as being a "gun loon," OK?
An AK-47 is a great rifle. I enjoyed killing plenty of paper targets and aluminum cans with one, but honestly, what is the need for one in our world? It's lousy for home defense (unless you think the gub'ment is going to smash thru your door) and worthless for hunting (unless you need multiple rounds to kill a deer), so what's the point? To balance that, who "needs" a car that goes 150 mph?
How do we balance "want" versus "need"?

Comment: I was one of the bikers who stopped to help these women. This occurred between two access points the sewage treatment plant and the Chalet. The point of this is that the moose are very territorial right now and do not need to be provoked to attack. Please be careful!

Comment: 1) A gamma emission is a gamma emission regardless of whether it comes from Radon, or Cesium (albeit with variations in emission energy, though that's captured in the dose conversion factors of any impact assessment methodology).  Background radiation in Canada, averages around 3mSv per year.  If the doses rates from the NSDF are orders of magnitude below that, (and they are, according to the EIS) then they ARE comparable with natural background radiation.  
2) My understanding is that the NSDF will have a 50 year operational life (accept wastes over a 50 year period) and then be closed, and become the permanent final disposal for that 50 years of waste.  Please provide a quote from the EIS if you believe I am mistaken.

Comment: Having driven from Toronto to Florida and back three times in electric cars I can assure you that this is not an issue. Comment: JH:
I absolutely agree with this general advice. As you indicate, each person may have somewhat different views of how comfortable they are with risk. Given this individual's relatively short two-year timeframe, the 100% guaranteed option is likely the right one for most people. If the capital had not been needed for five years some might consider putting, as just one example,  $100k into guaranteed investments and $50k into relatively low risk dividend payers like your model portfolio and as they get closer to that house purchase date, shift more dollars into fixed income out of stocks. The amount in each is a personal decision. Whatever one does, they need to be comfortable with and fully aware of all possible outcomes.     
Also maximizing the use of a TFSA is ideal for type of situation. 
Lastly, another investment possibility is a cashable GIC where the rate is guaranteed for one year but the GIC can be cashed either after 30 or 90 days depending on the institution.  
SFI

Comment: The CDC reports that there are about 20 million cases of Norovirus in the U.S. every year, a large fraction of them from restaurants.  "Infected food workers are frequently the source of these outbreaks, often by touching ready-to-eat foods, such as raw fruits and vegetables, with their bare hands before serving them."  Using gloves is no panacea, true, but it will help.  What would help even more would be a requirement that food workers be given paid sick leave.  Food workers are generally poorly paid as it is, and it is a hardship for them to take off from work when they are ill, so they have a strong incentive to come to work even when ill.  Many outbreaks of Norovirus are traced to this kind of situation.

Comment: The housing availability/affordability problem is not confined just to women and is not just the result of the  usual pandering to the elites, but is the consequence of several seemingly unrelated issues that the public broadly supports.  Would you answer negatively to any of these policy questions if you were asked - yet they all influence housing availability and cost:
1) Should Canada admit immigrants and refugees who want to come here for a better life?
2) Should Canada encourage foreign investment here, given that it creates jobs and wealth?
3) Should Canada try to limit urban sprawl, with the accompanying congestion and pollution?
4) Should Canada protect it's greenspaces and farmlands from development?
5) Should Canada require high standards of safety and energy efficiency in new or renovated residential buildings?
6) Should Canada help consumers by allowing cheaper imported goods and further shift our economy towards big city based services for those seeking employment?

2013)

Comment: At the moment, the Senate has the same power to defeat legislation as the House of Commons. Interestingly, the only apparent Constitutional definition of the Senate's power is in s. 18 of the Constitution Act 1867:
"18. The privileges, immunities, and powers to be held, enjoyed, and exercised by the Senate and by the House of Commons, and by the members thereof respectively, shall be such as are from time to time defined by Act of the Parliament of Canada, but so that any Act of the Parliament of Canada defining such privileges, immunities, and powers shall not confer any privileges, immunities, or powers exceeding those at the passing of such Act held, enjoyed, and exercised by the Commons House of Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, and by the members thereof." 
As I read that, an Act of Parliament could reduce the Senate's powers, perhaps to the same "delay but not veto" power that the British House of Lords has.

Comment: VAT is a tax on domestic consumption so a product purchased for use in Canada will bear an identical amount of tax regardless of whether it is produced in Canada or the US. To illustrate, a product with a fair market value of 100 is imported into Ontario from the US. The Canadian importer (distributor) pays 13% HST on the purchase price of the goods imported. The Distributor also purchases a product produced in Ontario at a price of 100 and has to pay 13% HST on that product as well. The distributor sells both products for 150 and charges 13%HST. The distributor files monthly HST return where they remit the HST on the Sales and claim a rebate on the HST paid on the purchases. The net effect is that HST is borne on the domestic consumption.

The US manufacturer is not disadvantaged at all compared to a domestic producer. They compete solely based on the price of their products.

Comment: Hi again TigerEye,

Back to the .50 AE (that pesky 999 character limit is often stifling).  As it turns out, the .50 AE is probably no better at penetrating flesh and bone than the now 61-year-old .44 Magnum.  It has everything to do with sectional density, the relationship of a bullet's diameter to its length.  Three hundred and even 350-grain .500-inch diameter bullets are relatively short and stubby especially compared to the projectiles used in rifle cartridges of the same approximate bullet diameter.  When you realize that 300-grain bullets are widely available in .44 Magnum loadings these days, it's no surprise that speaking of deer-size game, the .50 AE may benefit by punching a larger diameter entrance hole, but probably provides little, if any, greater penetration than the .44.

But returning to poor Ruiz, paper pages of small-book thickness can indeed stop some bullets.  Look up the now little-known (but Hollywood handsome) Old West gunman Dallas Stoudenmire for an example.

Comment: There is a big point of confusion about this push to get the electors to vote against Trump. And it is not just whining over Hillary's loss. Most democrats have accepted the loss. Yes, some still bring up the popular vote but that's irrelevant.

One of the purposes of the electoral college is, as you say, to make sure every state gets their say, although you'd think then there'd be 50 electoral college votes and not 538. But that's a different discussion for another time. The other purpose of the electoral college is to make sure that someone wholly unsuitable to be president does not get into office. 

It's not about popular vote, it's not sore losing, is that people are fearful that Trump is not qualified to be president and is a threat to the USA. If we expect to have a civil and meaningful conversation about this, we have to acknowledge that reason.

We should be debating whether or not Trump is suitable, not about whether popular vote matters, or who is a sore loser.

Comment: Clearly, the Trump phenomena will have an unsettling effect upon the Canadian vehicle manufacturing, forestry and other industries that are currently integrated on a North America wide basis or sell much of their product in the US.

However, we should all keep in mind that the US Federal Executive Branch (i.e. the Presidency) cannot act unilaterally to change the terms of Canada-US trade in fundamental ways, that many important US companies, industries, and States rely significantly upon Canada as a source inputs and markets, and that much of the current trade relationship is buttressed by international treaties.  It follows that, whatever bluster or implied threats are expressed, Canada has many advantages that it can deploy to defend its interests.

In short, while an implied threat exists and this will have a negative impact on the Canadian economy, the US also stands to suffer from this uncertainty.  The impact will be costly but the US will back off in most cases in the end.

Comment: This story ignores consequences for the refuge itself, a strange oversight.  Malheur has lost, or will lose, about a third of its staff to resignations or transfers.  This includes the entire scientific staff, all of whom are leaving this summer for new positions. 

The refuge archaeologist with 27 years experience on site? Going.  The fish biologist who has led the carp control efforts? Going. The other two biologists? Going.

In effect, the federal government decided to sacrifice the functionality of Malheur in order to preserve the Bundite perps from harm until they could be collected.  This was a humane solution but one that damaged public resources as well as the community (the Burns city manager and other valued local leaders have also left).  

It remains to be seen whether steps will be taken to rebuild Malheur's staff and protect the refuge and other public lands from future invasions.  If our refuges can be effectively dismembered by itinerant thugs, the Bundites win.

Comment: On of the most obvious costs of having high rates of gun ownership is accidental shootings and injuries. 

In 2015,there were more than 11,000 deaths from accidental shootings in the US, almost doubling the total number of gun related homocides, which were 13,000 not including gun suicides which were 21,000.

As accidental homocide is one of the harms of gun ownership, it has to be accounted for in the total.

If we were trying to establish, for example, do guns save lives ?   Let's say that there was a 30% reduction in crimes in states where everyone is armed to the teeth. But also a 50% increase in accidental homocides.

As people are irrational, the accidental homicide is acceptable to them. But the crime is not. 

The balance of the numbers point to the fact that increases in gun ownership result in decreases in public safety, due to the unintentional killings.

Imagine if someone "returns fire", and kills a bystander.

Comment: I think your analogy is actually very good, but I disagree with your conclusion. All insurance involves pooling and cost sharing - car, property, health, etc. - allocated according to risk. If you're at a higher risk of getting into a car accident and incurring costs within the "pool",  your premium is higher.  If you're at a higher risk of getting sick and incurring costs within the "pool", your premium should be higher. 

I think lots of the arguments on healthcare boil down to certain people believing healthcare is a basic human right versus a commodity. And others believing that the finest healthcare available is a basic human right.  But declaring excellent healthcare a basic human right would be massively expensive - requiring enormous government subsidies. Not too different from declaring Ferrari's is a basic human right. I think low-level, very basic, very cheap healthcare should be a part of the social safety net. But that's it. There's just not enough money for much more.

Comment: Very moving; thank you for writing.

Like others posting here, I see myself in some of the grief experiences.  Sobbing for the dead to “come home”.  Sharing the intimate language of two people that becomes so very lonely following death.

I envy you and others posting here what you aren’t experiencing; guilt.  Those times that come unbidden and super unwelcome when you recall everything from the trivial to the existential.  Why didn’t I go to that movie even though I don’t like science fiction?  Did I do the right thing going to the hospital and palliative care or if I had kept her at home would the whole trajectory of illness and death be different – or at least delayed. I think the guilt might be what gets many widows to suicide.

Comment: You are quite mistaken. Members of the cabinet, such a Cabinet Ministers and Prime Ministers, exercise in addition to legislative power, executive power.

Executive power is the setting of policies and directing departmental budgets.

Furthermore, they are privy to confidential information, which could be of value in commercial and market transactions.

For example, if someone knew that the government has a plan to invest in a particular area, and had bought real estate there in advance at a lower price with this knowledge - or alternatively if they influenced policy to serve a region where they owned real estate.

If they knew that a decision would affect the stock price of a certain industry and shorted their stock position - also known as insider trading.

However, if their assets are in a "blind trust", then presumably all their investments are at an arm's length - and they do not know where their assets are invested and cannot influence the investment.

Comment: As usual, the point of immigration is ignored. The reason for immigration is to serve policies relating to population growth and employment. We permit immigration on a large scale relative to the population to keep the population growing and to alleviate or prevent labour shortages. 

I think both of these policy goals are wrong-headed. It is not necessary for the population of Canada to grow. We have enough , and more than enough, people. We should be aiming for a policy that will stabilize the population immediately. I think that a slow (perhaps 0.1% per year) decline in the population would be optimum in the longer term.

As far as employment policy is concerned, the government should be trying to cause a labour shortage as a means to put upward pressure on wages. 

In short, while I am entirely indifferent to the ethnic, racial or religious makeup of the immigrant population, I think there should be a LOT less of them. Canada is full.

Comment: Smallpox was weaponized and used prior to 1776. Though never as wide-spread as popularly believed, items from the infirmary believed to be infected with smallpox were given as gifts during the Pontiac rebellion. 

William Trent, Commander of the militia in Pittsburgh wrote in his journal in May of 1763, "... we gave them two Blankets and an Handkerchief out of the Small Pox Hospital. I hope it will have the desired effect." 

Other contemporaneous correspondence also supports the practice.

Comment: Traditionally, Jews and Muslims are buried in a plain shroud, but the law required a coffin, so there was a plain pine coffin. The male relatives carried it to the grave. The rabbi recited the (four-line) El Male Rachamim, the mourners recited the (fifteen line) Mourner's Kaddish, the coffin was lowered into the grave and everybody took turns forking some dirt onto it. Then the miniature bulldozer finished the job. There was some ceremonial rending of garments, but obviously not real garments, just ribbons provided for the purpose.

No promises, no fantasies, no feudal pageantry, no exploiting the occasion to frighten anybody into being obedient. Nothing left to be said. If there is a God, the rest is up to Him. If there is not a God, the Jews will continue to worship Him, because that's what being a Jew is about.

I was impressed. Much more dignified, I thought. Kind of sorry I have to have the other thing, but of course, at that point I won't really care anymore.

Comment: The author summarizes why people are illegally entering Canada: "This is not, as some have said, a flaw in the act [Safe Third Country Agreement]; rather, it is a feature of the Canadian Constitution: Once in Canada, you are entitled to the full suite of rights – including due process and a fair hearing." The author, however, doe not mention why this is the case. The reason all non-Canadians who enter Canada, whether legally or not, have these rights is because of a Supreme Court decision which found that the Canadian Bill of Rights applies to non-Canadians once they are in Canada (see link below).  A simple way to change this would be for Parliament to use the notwithstanding clause to temporarily suspend that Court decision.  If that were to happen, all those that cross illegally into Canada from the U.S. could be sent back to the U.S, pursuant to the Safe Third Country Agreement. 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Singh_v_Canada_(Minister_of_Employment_and_Immigration

Just a few isolated examples where police have changed procedures. Do Have the country's forces adopted a nationwide set of standardized procedures? Unanimity on the meaning of "unfounded"? Comment: You're right, of course. The government could eliminate the mandate altogether. 

I have no problem with the general contraceptive mandate as long as those with religious and moral objections can opt out. Trying to force those groups to comply has not worked.

One reason those efforts didn't work is because the government failed to prove it had a "compelling interest" in compliance. A "compelling interest" is more than just a "good idea." It means the government has a clear and necessary goal that cannot be achieved in any way other than forced compliance. But as one court noted, if the government wanted all women to have free contraceptives, it could have simply passed a law providing all women with free contraceptives. In fact, the government does have programs that provide free or low-cost contraceptives. 

In short, the mandate was a "good idea" that never quite reached the level of "compelling interest." But it likely will be retained in some form.

Comment: The term "illegal", as in "illegal practitioner" or "illegal alien" is aptly used to describe someone who does something illegally.  No one seriously suggests that the person himself, rather than his action, is "illegal."  Furthermore, "illegal alien" is the term used by the U.S. Code.   That fact probably explains why the term is used.  People shorten expressions or terms in informal speech, and therefore use the shortened term "illegal" as a noun rather than an adjective to modify the noun "alien."  Big deal.

Comment: Let me repeat, for the record:  

Deady Hall, the first campus building, was named for Deady for his contribution to the University over decades - long after it was built.  And I don't mean his dollar contributions.  He didn't buy having a building named after him.  And the honor was given to him by those who had done the same. Deady Hall was built by a combination of tax money and voluntary donations from a whole bunch of (mostly) farmers who wanted to give their children and grandchildren a better education than they had themselves.  Many of those contributions were made in-kind, in the form of livestock or other products, sold for cash.

 Of course, Deady's views don't all jibe with ours today.  But the did comport with the views of his time.  When we dishonor him, we dishonor an entire generation.  It is the simple-minded hubris of the current day that demands we reject our own history. 

We are not teenagers - who know far more than their parents.  Let's not act like we are.

Comment: Hi Stuart,

Thanks for the reply/comment. 

While noting your point about your academic work (references welcome) and appreciating the constraints of word count, I still cannot see how any substantive analysis of such dynamics in economics could possibly reach the conclusions in, or that seem to be implied by, your article.

There is indeed a great deal to say about the role of peer review, and I am also busy with related work under the broad umbrella of 'philosophy of social science'. Economics is a particularly problematic case, partly because of the idea - propagated by neoclassical economists themselves since about 1900 - that it is like the sciences, when in many important ways it is not. That compounds all the concerns that would apply to scientific disciplines and creates many others.

In brief: peer review has its merits, but it is so crude as a basis for discerning the value of economic policy advice as to be almost useless except for the narrowest of questions.

Regards,
Sean

Comment: This opinion is spreading misleading information with 'the sky is falling' attitude of the author and ignores the long and rich history of the original indigenous inhabitants of what is now known as Alaska.  The opinion grossly inadequate in explaining the many legal jurisdictions that exist in Alaska today within the State-Federal-Tribal governance and jurisdictional realities.   Mr. Mitchell is wrong that the BIA will "begin taking title to land located any and everywhere in Alaska".  He insinuates from this false statement, that there will be a federal land grab and threats to local governments.  BIA will not be "taking title to land located any and everywhere in Alaska".   BIA will be accepting applications from Federally Recognized Tribes that have existing title to lands in Alaska, just like Tribes do in the other States in America.    The BIA has a comprehensive review that can take decades to process if the Trust application is even accepted.  Read Jenny Bell-Jones Opinion 7/4

Comment: I'm not sure about those numbers there Dante.  Data from NYSERDA shows the monthly electricity rates state wide from 2007 to 2017.  Here is the site (government data BTW):
www.nyserda.ny.gov/Researchers-and-Policymakers/Energy-Prices/Electricity/Monthly-Avg-Electricity-Residential
As an example, NY rates in January of 2007 were 16.1 cents / kWh vs 17.3 in January 2017.  They fluctuate year-to-year of course.  Looking only at January, those rates peaked in 2014 at 19.5 cents /kWh.
Rates aside, you need to compare apples with apples to see the big picture.  Look at the bottom line.  I care not what my rates are, I only care about the total monthly bill.
For example, we bought our home in 2009.  Our average monthly bill was $110 for the first 12 months.  Our highest in the period was $141 in the cold of February.  Today, our average monthly bill is $260, peaking at $295.  This is even after removing all incandescent bulbs (LED now) and replacing our electric stove & furnace with 100% gas.

Comment: Canada was losing industries to foreign competition before we had much in the way of trade agreements, before NAFTA, FTA, or WTO. Singapore and Hong Kong were favorites then ( Japan was regarded as expensive), and China wan't even on the horizon. We were dropping like a rock in terms of median incomes by then, and government seems to have felt that trade agreements would help. They didn't, and it is a mystery as to why Canadians don't see that now, after all these years of declines. The problem isn't trade agreements - it is international trade itself. The faster that we lock the door and ban foreign items, the faster businesses will tool up here to supply them. Who in their right mind would setup to make anything in Canada that can be made in a low wage countrys

Comment: I had two fail. In both cases the engines were non-interference engines, so the penalty was a tow. They failed at ~ 150% of the rcommended change interval.
For the interference engine with timing belt I have now (a TDI) I change after 150 000 km or 6 years whichever comes first.
Chains stretch (roller chains more than machine chains) and can cause issues too. If they fail it is not cheap even in the case of a non-interfence engine.
I prefer belts over chains, just because they are quiet, simple and reliable, and easy to change.

Comment: But you can use them to offset other medical expenses.

The benefits given to union workers now go above and beyond anything that was fought for in the beginning, far exceeding the original goals.
That said, I have no issue with private sector unions. 

Public unions however are a different animal. Spending tax payer dollars, from a position in which they can essentially hold hostage fellow hard working taxpayers that pay their wages and benefits.  This allows them to ask for compensation above what an employee doing the same job in the private sector could expect to receive for the same work.  Most workers in the private sector cannot get their employers to pay for coverage for their families, much less at such a high percentage. 

You could make the case that in turn the private sector should raise wages and benefits, but at that point you raise the spectre of public entities rigging the game against small business.  

This can of worms makes public sector unions a bad idea.

Comment: Injury is the pivot point. Team sports such as football, basketball, hockey have player unions that actively promote "owner accountability" for injury with just compensation when players are forced to retire due to injuries.  This pressure has led sports franchise owners to technologies which enable monitoring of motion and contact for best training practice and real-time risk evaluation, which is linked to insurance sharing this data. Best practices will attract lower premiums, higher risk methods will incur higher premiums.

Individual sports will follow the same regime.  Lower ranked players will risk injury more. As rank rises, insurance penalties and health/injury penalties will become more compelling disincentives.    Lastly, promoters will likely share liability for injuries to their tournament entrants.   For tennis, Turingsense.com is the point on the spear.  Top players have a pretty good idea how many swings they have in their career. Why wouldn't they use them wisely ?

Comment: I think epidemic is a fairly liberal use of the term.  Less than 1,000 people died in BC of overdoses.  The number in Ontario was a bit over 500.  

An epidemic is loosely defined as 15 cases per 100,000 population.  BC has about 4.6M people, meaning 6,900 overdoses would qualify as an epidemic.  BC has the worst opioid problem of any province.

1,000 people is 1,000 too many, no question.  But I think calling it an epidemic is a bit of an exaggeration.

Comment: In reply to aiea7's comment about "frivolous lawsuits":  There were two lawsuits that attempted to stop rail.  The one in federal court briefly affected the City’s ability to buy land in the downtown segment, but had absolutely no impact on rail construction or construction bidding.  HART eventually acknowledged that this lawsuit increased rail costs by less than one-tenth of one percent ($6,321,002). The other lawsuit was brought in state court by Paulette Kaleikini because the City had started construction without first conducting an archaeological study, as is required by law.  A unanimous state Supreme Court ordered construction stopped until the City completed the study.  That took 13 months and, according to HART, cost $495,331 in litigation costs and another $39,039,250 in other “impacts.”  How can a unanimous Supreme Court victory be termed “frivolous?” .....

Comment: unfortunately, SMCRA only effects the coal operators and does not address the hard rock (metal mines). there is a world of difference between the two, metal mines are also required to post bonding for reclamation but don't get administered the same way. the bonding requirements (coal) are laid in law (federal) and administered by OSM (Office of Surface Mining) through the states. for example, a mine here in Alaska (Healy) is required to perform a reclamation estimate that follows the federal guidelines, must use a standardized estimating tool such as RSmeans and wage rates, such as Davis-Bacon for the area they are located in. the estimate is then reviewed and approved by the governing agency (DNR). if the State approves an estimate that doesn't cover the costs then who's fault is it?

Comment: To provide such an example is fairly simple, once you understand the structure of the SA "basic" education system.
In a simplified analysis, there exist three classes of schools:
1. Totally state-operated schools.
2. Partially state-operated schools (probably the majority, and particularly including the "former model-C" schools)
3. Totally private schools.
Of those, the first two classes report, in non-academic activities, wholly or partially to government, and can be regulated in terms of their religious policies.  
The third class are only regulated in terms of their academic curriculum being directed towards the same matric examinations, but otherwise they are free to set their own rules, particularly in religious matters.  In that way, there are some church-operated Christian schools, some Moslem schools, and some operated by the Jewish community.  All of these will show strong religious preferences.
The OGOD matter seems to be directed basically at the second group.

Comment: The problem with Krugman's thinking, if it is indeed possible to limit that to only one problem, is that all his solutions revolve around spending more taxpayer dollars with the hope that preventive use of medicine will reduce the overall cost, then assuming everyone's costs will eventually go down. Sadly, there is no evidence of that dynamic ever working in the long run. In fact, as an economist, Krugman should know that it is contrary to basic economic principles. When people are getting something for below market price or for free because others are paying the difference, they will tend to use more of it. As that happens, and since there are always limits to tax dollars and the political costs of deficit spending, rationing happens by various means. For Medicaid, it is doctors dropping out of that market, leaving those reliant on it with longer waits and lower quality doctors and care, even as our overall expenditures on Medicare go up. Even a Nobel prize winner can be wrong.

Comment: To those screaming that the RG supports taxes constantly, please go back to its full-throated opposition to Measure 97 just last fall.  And that was not the first time it opposed a new tax.  And for those that scream that all the state can do is spend money, recognize that we do have a rainy day fund.  
The kicker, combined with an income tax, is supremely stupid because it exacerbates economic cycles.  More money is given out during good times, and we have less during bad times.  At the very least the state should keep the first 1.99% and add it to the rainy day fund.  The discontinuity that occurs at 2% is absolutely senseless and likely a mistake in the drafting of the proposal that got us this dreadful law.

Comment: If Trump is not subject to conflict of interest laws, so be it. But how about Ivanka wearing the bracelet that she sells on that 60 Minutes piece a couple months ago, then after the piece airs her people are emailing a "Style Alert" to reporters to talk up "Ivanka Trump Fine Jewelry" and how that bracelet she was just seen wearing on 60 Minutes can be had for $10,500? How about Trump's first version of his transition website (that's a .gov address, you and I own it) blabbing about what an amazing business he has built and touting all his great properties around the world. These people are shameless, and this will be a constant distraction and embarrassment for the country. Perhaps distraction is exactly what Trump is looking for.

Comment: The fantasy here is that we can continue to add highway lanes in perpetuity.  Denver is already swamped with cars. Adding highway lanes to I-25 to allow more cars into the city only adds to the problem. Maybe bus-only lanes running a BRT Bustang service would be cheaper and easier than actual rail, but the idea that cars will continue the best way to move around the metro is myopic.

Comment: What next?  Pet support like child support?  I love my pets, but, really, this is going way too far.  Judges have enough to deal with, without having to now take on this as a matter of law.  I do know that judges have in the past had to deal with pet ownership, costs, etc., but to make this a requirement is just too far....
